newsitem.title: GERMANY: Lan Chile does not plan Autumn rates rise.
newsitem.headline: Lan Chile does not plan Autumn rates rise.

text.p: Lan Chile plans to keep air cargo rates out of Europe to Latin America stable this autumn, said cargo manager Europe, Martin Rehs.
He told Reuters in an interview: "We do not plan any rise. In the low season, we have been able to keep our rates fairly stable and at a relatively high level."
Rehs added he did not want to cash in after clients had paid relatively high rates during the low season.
The airline operates Boeing 767-300 passenger flights four times a week from Frankfurt via Madrid to Santiago and also operates ad-hoc freighters out of Europe, he said.
Rehs added: "Lan Chile comes on to the market as a relatively high price carrier. We will wait and see, but the prime aim is not to raise rates but to increase tonnage."
Lufthansa Cargo AG, Air France, Martinair and Lan Chile all have relatively equal shares of the Europe to Chile market, he noted.
Competition is higher on ad-hoc business, particularly from U.S. carriers such as Polar Air Cargo, he noted.
Goods carried to Chile include pharmaceutical goods, fertilisers, car spare parts and general industrial goods, while top Chilean air cargo exports to Europe are fish and fruit, he added.
"I am very optimistic about Chile although as a small country it has a limited market," he said.
Rehs described Argentina as the largest Latin America market but noted competition out of Europe is very strong with a rising numbers of freighter services.
The Spanish market to Peru is expanding thanks to investment by Spanish telecommunications company Telefonica in the country, he said.
"There is a large market out of Spain. There are several projects there and we have increased freighter flights from Chile to Lima," he said.
Lan Chile is also seeing ex-Europe to Mexico growth driven by production facilities of European car manufacturers Volkswagen and Renault, he said.
"Mexico is a very large market which is characterised by several large clients such as Volkswagen which is carrying a vast amount of cargo from Seat in Spain to Mexico," he said.
"In France we see three daily, full freighters flying to Mexico and the cargo potential is there," he added.
